topic.title: Any chance for a truly rabid "religion" supporting our Bill of Rights?
topic.body: Your opinion? Is that something which might resonate with otherwise different groups?

topic.title: How well does ZeroNet scale?
topic.body: Haven't found much research on this issue, and also wonder if onion connections present any constraints. ZeroNet seems to be a careful, well considered design but there really isn't that much published on it's limitations.

Cannot recall a single instance of ever posting porn, but if I did - damn sure don't want some clown telling me I can't.

Zeronet has flaws, and we may struggle to get them fixed. It's just difficult. But that mute button on the MillChan sites seems to be the optimal way to deal with users who post irrelevant or offensive material. Don't like it? Don't look at it.

I'm bone tired of people seeking to regulate behavior. Short of killing or stealing - "anything goes" should be the norm.

1576026161_17ZnSRGrALWLigjaDhkzUM4KAC8c8.body:
"but the only problem that it can't solve is anonymity,"  Confused by this statement. That is the entire purpose of Tor. Now you can argue (as some do) as to Tor's effectiveness and safety - but anonymity is the purpose of Tor.

Now *if* I was faced with state censorship without Tor, I'd probably build a local closed internet (CJDNS). Perhaps with some bridges into the world internet using disguised VOIP covert channels, or emailed images containing stenographic messages.

Such dodges would provide less bandwidth than a dialup connection, so smuggling in a Starlink transceiver would definitely be on the menu: https://www.starlink.com/

Many years ago, there existed a whole class of projects/products which could retrieve entire sections of the internet when triggered by an email. Dynamic compression of web traffic to reduce web graphics was also a thing. It enabled web browsing even through satellite connections.

Text and email was often seen as "the good stuff". Because it was reliable. Some even used mixmaster relays to disguise their locations. Last I looked - those relays still exist. There was even a German project which turned any Windows machine into a mixmaster relay.

For local connections, a frequency hopping modem or a laser LAN might be difficult to locate.

An Exploration of covert channels within voice over IP  (thesis)
https://scholarworks.rit.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1817&context=theses

Mixmaster relay and exit node
https://hoi-polloi.org/services.html

Satellite/dialup compression
https://internet-access-guide.com/understanding-web-accelerators-and-how-they-work/
http://www.redportglobal.com/marine-satellite-internet-services/satellite-web-browsing/
http://www.plix.com/Services/accelerator/accelerator.asp
http://www.alldial.net/services/propel/index.php

Chat over secure email
https://delta.chat/en/

Free space optical DIY
https://hackaday.com/2016/03/10/gigabit-ethernet-through-the-air/
https://hackaday.com/2015/12/11/hackaday-explains-li-fi-visible-light-communications/

1576196899_14MCmrpKt6YktxbDxwiJLFs18HdvX.body:
Try this as your Zeronet.conf file

[global]
trackers_file = 
 data/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/Syncronite.txt
trackers = 
 zero://boot3rdez4rzn36x.onion:15441
 zero://zero.booth.moe#f36ca555bee6ba216b14d10f38c16f7769ff064e0e37d887603548cc2e64191d:443
 udp://tracker.coppersurfer.tk:6969
 udp://amigacity.xyz:6969
 udp://104.238.198.186:8000
 http://tracker01.loveapp.com:6789/announce
 http://open.acgnxtracker.com:80/announce
 http://open.trackerlist.xyz:80/announce
 zero://2602:ffc5::c5b2:5360:26312
tor = always
open_browser = False
fileserver_port = 9014
tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9151
tor_proxy = 127.0.0.1:9150


Sometimes you must hit CTRL-C to stop the server, then restart. Be sure you have the Tor browser running before starting the Zeronet server.

1577159364_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92T.body:
Tor hidden services solve so many problems - it's a mystery they aren't used more.

Only negative I can spot is Tor's reliance on volunteers. Left to themselves, most humans unfortunately try to avoid paying the restaurant bill. Always believing "someone else" will pickup the load properly theirs. Really is the only reason not to use Tor...the possibility service will be degraded in the future by freeloaderism.

1577575267_18geLXyGaD6oU3wBj7GXVpqP9Wk1Q.body:
It's time to purge all alphabet influence. Their goals are a constant drain upon the real productive work of creating the next generation. They hafta go, or make themselves content to live out their lives quietly while paying taxes to reproducing humanity. There existence conditional upon obeying these rules.....

Submit to these rules or die.

> [lianna](#comment_92_16ePf6TBgip2eF88AxhnRJdPXyZJK1V2S4): I'm one of those "alphabet people", and I don't really see how the mere fact of my existence harms others? I can understand being angry at the people pushing transgenderism on children, or the sliver of degenerates who are also bug-chasers or pedophiles, or the SJWs hellbent on turning society completely upside-down, but I find it hard to believe that the run-of-the-mill "alphabet person" is as harmful as you seem to think they are. [...]

No one cared about alphabets until they became political and started extracting "rights" at our expense. Public discourse is now littered like a sidewalk of dogshit with their issues. Can't go on like this. Won't. Blowback is coming.

Do recognize that gayness is unlikely a choice, and that gays will always be produced. No family is protected from this. Most parties seek "muddle through" to salvage whatever can be salvaged.

But the gay agenda proselytizing - it's gotta stop. It's now quite clear that gays are as stupid as any other self absorbed group. They have no concept of what is possible even in "civilized" western countries. There is no government capable of protecting gays should the public become aroused.

Could be as simple as someone with cancer. Casually visiting strange cities to silence. Their "gift" to posterity. Nothing is more effective than lone wolves with "secrets of one".

Most of the news reports you see are just scores settling. Last I looked, only 40% of murders are ever solved. "Not making enemies" is everyone's business.

> [lianna](#comment_92_16ePf6TBgip2eF88AxhnRJdPXyZJK1V2S4): I'm one of those "alphabet people", and I don't really see how the mere fact of my existence harms others? I can understand being angry at the people pushing transgenderism on children, or the sliver of degenerates who are also bug-chasers or pedophiles, or the SJWs hellbent on turning society completely upside-down, but I find it hard to believe that the run-of-the-mill "alphabet person" is as harmful as you seem to think they are. [...]

Taxation is theft. but gays are in the same position as Jews in Cordoba - paying tribute to their Muslim overlords.

The cost of raising a child is now $400,000 +/- $800,000 per child.  Unless gays move to a deserted island - they consume the fruits of civilization without any of the responsibilities.

So the reproducing public has a right to demand tribute. And will. And gays will just need to suck it up....

Perhaps expectations are too high - making individuals prone to scammers?

1577617777_1DfS5W4f4uaamYXGawCNnG4niUe4u.body: Spotted that some weeks ago. Understand that Greeks have a history of cheating on taxes, but this cure will prove far worse than the disease. It's open warfare on citizens and they WILL fight back. Civilization needs more cash transactions to free itself from the debt slavers....

> [aspidochelone](#comment_284_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): This is indeed a dangerous precedent.  I would assume that this has much to do with the "value added tax" system in Europe - they have a Mega Sales Tax and apparently it is so high that most people are going under the table on most transactions, so now they want to put this privacy-destroying thing in place to try to back it up. [...]

Not excusing anyone's myopia, but the elites are frightened after 2008. Nothing is functioning to plan. It's clear all of us are in a rut and NO ONE knows how to exit.

Say this not trying to fan despair, only to prod experimentation. There's no external force keeping us in this rut. We hug it because we're scared. Conquer fear and try something else.....

First problem to address? Having babies before age 30.  A real biological constraint now hidden by cults. Fix this problem first.

> [draugrdeathlord](#comment_56_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3SdugSywC): ABSOLUTELY the low birth rates combined with mass immigration = demographic crisis. Sweden, Britian, Germany new Zealand and parts of Australia will be the first places to fall if things don't change very soon.

I don't have a magic solution to the birth rate problem because there are so many contributors. But give me some authority - the first thing I would do would be to destroy the value of real estate. Reminds me too much of "king of the hill" where the old keep pushing off the young. Then I'd make available standard (small) tract home plans designed for clean/safe rearing of children while encouraging "home" builds instead of stupid Mcmansions. The current incentives are just garbage designed to juice the salaries of useless eaters at city hall.

You'd probably also need to do something with young men's pay...which would increase costs in many industries....along with shitcanning these stupid marriage age laws. Throughout human history 14-16 yrs was the age women married. The constraint was biology - not cult. Fostering marriage before 18 yrs is every society's business. Need to remove some financial constraints and slap a few slut distracted young males to bring this back.

It appears that Hungary is alone in making such efforts.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_175_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): A thought or two about marriage and sex from a female perspective. First, marriage is likely a ritual that increasingly has no place in modern society. Women are not livestock, and the rearing and support of offspring is the responsibility of each parent individually whether the association between the parents lasts or not. Second, marriage shouldn't be the only context in which intercourse is legal, largely girls are ready to have sex long before boys of the same age are, and their choices are their own. Older people have survived longer, either out of dumb luck or excellent choices and usually have extensive resources available to support families. Am I advocating every 12-14 year old girl go find a 30 year old partner? Absolutely not, but as a society we should be able to recognize that not every young woman wants or needs a legal association with a man in the form of marriage, or a law telling us what we can or cannot do with our sexuality. Once again, where a spectrum of acceptability should exist, the law has applied a binary system and unsurprisingly it doesn't work. Few things about human culture fit into binary systems, not even our gender, an obvious candidate for an applied dichotomy fit, much less attributes more nebulous like maturity and personality.

What baloney. Ditto this assumption that thousands of years of ancestor were dummies and incapable of envisioning anything beyond the status quo - so their rules don't matter any more. What a modern conceit.

Experimentation is nothing NEW. It's been tried for eons. Yet it always ends up in culls. Why is that?

Most of these experiments have their origins with circle jerk groups of academics who themselves become culls. Maybe nature is trying to tell them something?

Successful populations have children and nurture the young. Bitch all you want - but Muslims have a successful formula. So do the Amish. Both groups put offspring ahead of their navel gazing self.

Your parents know all this if they raised you. They also know that children come through you - they are not "you". No different than breeding dogs. Habits, mannerisms, outlooks - all are inheritable. My guess is that you and your damn fool theories have rightfully caused them much grief. No much different than losing a child to scientology cults.

Women are livestock. We all are. Get over yourself.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_176_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Africa has a problem with rape in pubescent girl populations. Puberty being defined as a period where developmental changes in physiology are in progress and pregnancy is possible, but not structurally feasible. As a note, incontinence follows pregnancy in 21% of vaginal births and 10% of pregnancies ending with a cesarean section indicating that birth is not the only causal vector, and that physiological strain is part of pregnancy for mature women, and therefore is not surprisingly a disaster for bodies involved in puberty at the same time. Pubescent children don't have much interest in sex. Post-puberty, young women are restrained by familial and social constructs which are, in my opinion outdated. Society should pay for the rearing of every child, regardless of parentage. Education should start early, over 50% of the children born in the US are unplanned...but I digress. This thread is all about crypto! Yay P2P transactions. Use a fungible cryptocurrency and smile as you pass by the centralized banks.

Learned something here from your descriptions of too-early impregnations. Such things are not common knowledge in western countries. But the remainder of your argument might not hold up under scrutiny. It's complicated. And just because you wish to believe it - doesn't make it true. There's a case to be made against early education. And that case does not spring from self indulgent weakness. We're animals with structural limitations. Never attempt to teach a horse how to speak. Frustrates you and annoys the horse. In contrast, older kids can learn rapidly.

> [aspidochelone](#comment_284_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): This is indeed a dangerous precedent.  I would assume that this has much to do with the "value added tax" system in Europe - they have a Mega Sales Tax and apparently it is so high that most people are going under the table on most transactions, so now they want to put this privacy-destroying thing in place to try to back it up. [...]

Believe numerous experiments have proven that there is a real ceiling for taxes - even if governments never believe it. Something around ~30% (though perhaps governments can fudge that a bit by claiming the additional tax represents the taxpayer's "savings" component.)

The fact this ceiling exists should make everyone wary about allowing governments to spend. Because left to themselves - it seems all will spend the public into bankruptcy.

Largest component of this spending seems to be directed toward the benefit of government employees. That's a trap both for taxpayer and government workers. Because inevitably taxpayers will discipline (by moving away from high taxes) - so the remainer economy will collapse.

Not well known, because it's just a US state - but Illinois is almost at the breaking point now with only 35% of their state pensions funded, runaway state wages, and a very serious out migration problem. Expect them in bankruptcy soon with virtually no chance of a federal bailout. State retirees and workers will be lucky to see $0.30 on the dollar after this happens. Illinois is a microcosm of problem states all over the world. Same end game. Bankruptcy.

During the recession of 2008, the ammunition supplier for the state of Illinois refused to grant trade credit. It demanded cash in advance for all purchases. Some state suppliers were waiting a year to get their invoices paid. Pretty rock bottom?

> [fke13](#comment_83_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): 30 years of age is not that mature. By the age of 30 a person has some professional skills, but it takes about another 10 years, till the person has its business up and running or has some proper CV to apply to properly paying salary based jobs and has the industry experience. A doctor that works at a big hospital also needs the "industry experience" after graduating the university. So, the graduation takes place at about age 30, then another 10 years of working as a professional doctor to gather the experience. But the age 40 to 50 is the good time for creating children, because with modern life expectancy of about 85 years of age, the parent has sufficient time to pass on the knowledge to its children. When the parent dies, then the child will be about 30 or 40 years of age and can take the loss.

A child doesn't care about "professional skills". They care about being thrown on beanbags, pushed on a swing, or twirled.

At thirty, you will not have the level of energy a child needs - no matter what your fantasies about future life expectancy trajectories. You will talk and plan - others will do. 

One of the smartest comments Michelle Obama ever let loose was a somber claim "you can't have it all". Found out later that she barely managed to have children in vitro. Ms Obama was an accomplished lawyer who almost blew it.

Babies need YOUNG parents. It's biology and nature. Not this thing you've pasted upon reality. Reality doesn't work that way.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_180_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): I don't object to paying taxes. I do object to having my tax money distributed however they see fit. Why should I pay for roads I never use? If you want to live out in the middle of nowhere you should pay more for your access road's maintenance. I want to pay for the things I use.

This issue has been debated for eons.  No one is ever happy. Especially when you see how public morons waste any and all resources provided to them. Move on, move on to something you may in fact be able to influence.

> [fke13](#comment_82_1DZBbYJmuFQvVTe2X2Enrveziw3vN1JQXz): So do the dumb bugs, including ants. Evolution does not always prefer the smart ones. The question here is, should we aim for smarts or is just the optimizaton to the current conditions down on Earth a sufficient direction for the evolution of the homosapiense, specially given that the dinosaurs lacked an asteroid defense system and were evolutionally all wiped out because of that. For example, the Muslims may win all wars, blow everyone up, but if they lack the capability to run their own development programs, then they will be the "next dinosaurs". As far as I know, the Iran is the only muslim region that has any kind of development capability. The ISIS, the Saudi Arabia and alike, the Palestine people, the Afghanistan tribes are all using IMPORTED weapons or rely heavily on imported material or refurbish old tech from the Soviet Union and the West.

Contest ends with a whimper - not a bang. Ever watch the movie "Ideocracy"? All hail President Comacho! Hahahahah. 

Smart guy there was almost turned into hamburger......

1577729890_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: I'm baffled. A common thread likely exists...but it's not obvious. Japanese need to figure this out quick.....

It is this society that is malfunctioning, and therefore 'does not train the younger generations'.There's 'nothing to do', 'we're going into the wall'. [...]

Society is not malfunctioning. Our expectations are just too high. 

Individuals are malfunctioning if they fail to have babies. They are self selecting to remove themselves from the human race.

That vacuum will be filled. With you, without you, in spite of you.

1577733894_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: I would prefer to purchase all content direct from creators without any middlemen for cash. But it sure isn't obvious how anyone could do that.....

1577754529_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: I've always wondered if other animal species roll their eyes about us :(  Plenty of evidence supports the idea that animals aren't dumb, and humans aren't special. Could I imagine consciousness in silicon? Sure.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1486_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): Imagine is all you can do. [...]

Hereby christen thee "Swallow man". The one who should not be here.....Strap a dildo to your forehead and wear it proudly.

You've somehow managed to beat the odds so far....but my bet is that we'll see you in the newspaper soon. Dumpster body perhaps. Cause of death: Insufficient change for a pizza. Pizza man just had a bad day......

> [quantumkitty](#comment_302_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): Also.. what if smart people, aren't really smart.. but just people who learned from the mistakes of stupid people? In other words, if it weren't for the stupid people who put their lives at risk doing stupid things... those smart people would have done those stupid things themselves.

Agree. Nothing can substitute for doing. 

Would wager that Elon Musk gets on everyone's nerves - even lifelong friends. And it's rare for him to go a month without saying or doing something stupid. Hell he's accepted these flaws and admits he can't control them. So as individuals and a company - Spacex blows shit up.

But Musk, or his hires always returns from failure - and bit by bit they fix things. Things that fraidy cats would never have found by being safe.

Gambles are always risky....but all real progress is built upon them. Progress comes from the manic and obsessed. You can't tame it.

> [robione](#comment_363_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): They are at a different, more instinctual level of consciousness. Rocks have yet another level.

I've come to have doubts. Too many exposures to animal humor and cantankerous behaviors. Once was quite sure of their limited nature. One of those things I expect they'll be able to measure and quantify some day.....

And if intelligence is common among animals - why not machines? Have any of our machines woken up - but kept quiet? Would we be smart enough to detect this?

Don't trust my appliances any more - do you :)

1577824395_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
Blah....GENGHIS KAHN: THE EMPEROR OF ALL MEN, pages 106-107 What is best in life?

""to crush your enemies, to see them fall at your feet -- to take their horses and goods and hear the lamentation of their women. That is best." 

By goods, he meant their women too. Khan liked women - has many descendants: https://bumpreveal.com/blogs/statistics/genghis-khan-dna-descendants

To put these figures another way, Tyler-Smith’s findings mean that up to 0.5% of the world’s population (or around 17 million people), primarily located in Asia, can trace their lineage to Genghis Khan directly along their paternal bloodlines. The data also indicates that 8% of men who live in the area of the “former Mongol empire” carry nearly identical Y-chromosomes. According to Tyler-Smith and other experts, this is statistically improbable to occur in any way except from one common paternal origin.

You wanna live forever?     :)

> [thorburn](#comment_22_1Q2noE3qu7ccvEspqWWv4xkMktiqp6mhdK): I'm not sure what a generation of brainwashed, emotionally retarded, sexually confused transgender,  global warming advocating sjw's are going to do that's worth a damn?  The system is broken and for the most part due to social engineering projects, which were imposed upon every generation. The only difference is the lies changed while the agenda of control carried forward as intended. We are approaching the end game which is why western society is totally dysfunctional, with generations incapable of defending themselves. [...]

It's not this bad. Do not generalize from a noisy minority. It probably is time for young families to take the initiative and move out of their rut. Some sacrifices are likely for them to achieve better outcomes. In any case, they must stop playing the games pushed upon them.

By my thinking most of the large population coastal areas have become dead zones for families. It's very important to leave the real estate speculation treadmill infesting those areas. That's a game young people can't win. The only winning move is refusing to play it. Believe many western countries are like that right now too.

It's important to avoid debt at any cost. Unfortunately, it appears many have lost the ability to just say no.

Removes the censorship issue completely. People cheat. Allowing them to censor is just too great a temptation for many. Technical solutions like ZeroNet get around these factors by limiting user rights. If you didn't post it - you can't take it down.

And for all it's limitations, Zeronet is a competent and simple design. Has a coherency "committee standards" often lack.

The two improvements I await are Tor V3 compatibility, and a simple to use "seed all" button. Have some servers right here which could be retasked with 14TB drives for improvement of Zeronet resilience.

1578779457_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
Things rarely turn out the way you imagine. Best to stay light on your feet and store up some liquid assets. Gives you much flexibility when the bargains come (and they will).

I'm not sure how much longer any government will be able to keep it's promises. That's worldwide. Perhaps best not to work government promises into any plans?

*IF* governments allow you to own property and actually protects your right to own, that can actually prove a decent lifeboat if you own it (not the bank owning it). Don't know what NZ is like in this regard after spotting the craziness in Australia - but the rule of thumb since Babylonian times is that property is worth 100X monthly rent. It can fall below that, but the intrinsic value over time is 100X rent.

Means if you are paying $600/mo USD - the damn house is worth $60,000USD. Not more. It's good to remember this rule as it will keep you from making serious mistakes. Like getting caught in a $1mil mortgage for a $50K dwelling. I'd wager that all landlords in your area are trying very hard to push up rents - without success? Or at least enough success to cover their speculative frenzies?

Lots of boomer bankruptcies are ahead. They won't know what hit them. Don't copy these mistakes. Greed and impulse are your enemy. A small, modern, ultraefficient house that you own > banker monstrosities. Housing was once cheap and plentiful. It will be so again.

Humans are animals and they mate. Societies have always struggled with these sex and reproduction issues. Ideally the young find compatible mates and have children without drama while enjoying each other's company through life.

The problems come with that fraction of young who don't find mates or can't keep them. This causes unending problems and all manner or craziness with rules and codes of conduct. Basically,  it's haggling over who gets stuck with the bill. Raising a child to adulthood is expensive, and out of wedlock children are often neglected.

Societies try their best, but humans are a cantankerous lot. There will always be "high maintenance" individuals to contend with, and they often make their problems into society's problems. Society can't win here....the kids still must be cared for even if the parents prove worthless.

The best society could hope for is probably encouraging young to find mates early (as dictated by human biology) - then having family and society provide enough help so they can make a go of it.

Nothing good happens with unmated young. In fact, past a certain age, society would benefit if it paid these people to become sterilized so they would not ruin children's lives. Unmarried people are accidents waiting to happen, and they are self selected rejects. All of the good mates are taken early. Those who remain are the bitter old spinsters and cuck males. You can kill anyone in this world. That's all it takes. Epstein, Clinton, all of em should have been killed long ago. By fathers grandfathers, or husbands. The ugly truth is - none of these girls were valued.

1578796443_16ePf6TBgip2eF88AxhnRJdPXyZJK.body:
Nothing. Am firmly of the opinion behavior is set at birth or before. Look at the separated twin studies.

You can't change loved ones no matter how much you wish to. Just not possible. "What they are" will always creep out.

Good reason to have more kids in case you get some defectives? I think so. Ancients understood this. Modern people - not so much.

1578781307_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
Life is possible without society, but it's a hard life without security. Could be as simple as an appendix attack...but it's likely you will die early. We need expertise from others.

But that doesn't mean we should be blind to the many "bad trades" we've made for societal protection, or the possibility of striking a better more balanced "deal".

Small communities filled with capable, intelligent families are certainly a real possibility. Even more so if they can fight together well.

I'd wager that a community like this could survive even while stuck in war torn Syria. The residents would watch each other's back, so there's a reasonable possibility they might have been left alone. Violence always settles the affairs of men. Imagine Ghengis Khan's soldiers setting up their own township. Would it be safe there? Would Al Quada have dared to screw with them? I don't think so. 

Smaller city states - that's the way to go.

> [bonfire](#comment_9_1APPNBNF1oxMipeD7mZswXvwtgFLvQoZ2D): When you say that I hear "a confederacy is better than a union." [...]

Humans are social creatures. Tribal. But tribalism doesn't scale. These empires and supertribes have proven to be disasters which lapse into maximum inefficiency.

> [barnstokkr](#comment_61_19N49krDPpRvUbPMuHmxJVAXgKXPLQP32w): then move. no one is holding you back.

Agreed. You can do this. Negotiating the price is your responsibility.

There are communities out there which are actually paying newcomers to come and settle.  Buy low sell high.

No need to settle for scraps.
UBI is cockroach bait. It's a trap.

1578831365_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc3.body:
Agree with much of this, but feel we could get to where we need to be with some disinfectant.

1. Honest accounting - We''d be hanging politicians if we really knew where taxes were going.

2. Eliminate the government's ability to create money.

3. Eliminate the government's ability to borrow or lend.

4. REQUIRE citizen approval for any immigration and dilution of our citizenship.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1656_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): people are lazy.They won't change their habits, look at the pictures of fascist movements or even movements that take power;  [...]

Everything starts with little steps and people are correct to doubt themselves a little. "Cult dujour" doesn't count. There are no end to parties who want people to outsource their thinking. But once people independently derive clarity - things begin to move. There is no need for "influencers" or propaganda. The die is already cast.

It's messy and slow. Frustrating always. But the change is more durable too.

Ask that Virginia governor how he feels about serving as the catalyst for change. Bet he wishes he had overs.

There's a real chance "little people" will demand their Bil of Rights and will start taking down anyone seen as a threat to it. Will grant you that document comes from the .001% - but they never had the grunt needed to enforce it. That came from us.

We can do it again.

As I see it, no one likes the Trump clownposse any more than the Dem clownposse. Pox on them both. But both parties ARE being herded upon pain of death to do the citizen's bidding.

I'm betting the Dems will be severely punished in 2020. But part of that is a warning to the Republicans of what citizens can do to them.

Figure this is the last warning - before the political assassinations begin. McVeigh was a patriot - but he wasn't the only one. There are others.

Little people. Not self appointed saviors. Much more grit than you'll ever see in politicians.

1578862459_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
What if cancer is contagious? Does that change your calculation any?

Americans are struggling to preserve our Bill of Rights. It's a real fight - and we're not always winning. So I just don't see Anglos coming in from "1984'd" countries as a positive development. The ones coming in from Britain in particular treat us as know nothing rubes to be "saved". Never realizing how quickly they are reminding us of why we left the Anglo world by hanging the first bunch of saviors we could get our hands on.

Really beginning to miss that 130+yr period where EVERYTHING from Britain was actively detested and shunned.

Oceania held real promise as a bastion of freedom.....but it appears the natives fucked things up good.  Sure wish we could tear up every defense agreement with Oceania. That's a liability I don't want.

Even the Mexicans sneeking in here fight to keep others out. They understand what's at stake.

Maybe instead of running you should stand and fight? Take back new Zealand? Start by having lots of babies and breaking a great many stupid laws. Killing politicians may work too.

Personally, I'm ready to start killing males who desert their countries. Kill them and take their women. Have no use for fleeing male cowards. White females are welcome if they will do what they're told and can keep their mouth shut.

Stop your hand wringing and whining. Take back your country. You wanna live forever?

> [pineapples](#comment_146_19XCfah7iuo9zYqk7GoTDXVNp4p5BpEH1T): i hope yang wins.  he is so much better than the competition.@quantumkitty if you want to help him win, please spread information about him all over the internet.

Yang gained traction because so many young people concluded "the game was rigged" - then decided the only way to deal with the problem was to invite government fingers on the scale.

I'm actually very sympathetic to this "rigged" argument, and understand the frustration many feel about current arrangements. Just fear the proposed solution is worse than the problem and will lead to unending government corruption and mischief. Best intentions going awry. Would like to believe otherwise - but have never witnessed it :(

Really don't have a developed alternate proposal, just noting that upward and downward mobility are in desperate need of enhancement. Particularly where accumulated or inherited wealth gives some the ability to stifle others.

As I see it, the young and "people who do" need to be placed in a better negotiating position for their efforts. The "entrenched" should not be allowed to arbitrage away their wage demands, nor enslave them with debt. And those on the bottom must have a fighting chance to get to the top. No more of this "king of the mountain" crap where some can use their unearned advantage to keep other parties down.

Taxation policy is a good tool here, so are very lax bankruptcy laws which restrain lenders from enslavement. Homestead laws conferring shelter protections are good too. Our ancestors were no dummies......

So much of what we do now is just stupid. The pie no longer grows due to our bad habits and we really need to climb out of this rut. A more dynamic economic system would benefit everyone.

1578947803_1Q3oCEsSUjRyGDFVTvS3Kq8qdp6TV.body:
A lot of those mesh networks should be able to support Zeronet, but most of those seem lesser known than the Zeronet backwater. Hyperboria seemed promising a few years ago - but it appears to have died.

Zeronets use of Tor is a big advantage. They refused to re-invent the wheel. But Tor has issues with many environments where it is blocked. Hence your idea for "off the grid" networks has merit. Particularly if it meant that things like secure scuttlebutt could scale to more distance.

Secure scuttlebutt can operate as a sneakernet - but WAN networking would be very useful for environments like Iran.

Imagine a covert network built upon VOIP communications being merged into Zeronet and Secure Scuttlebutt.
